lessons.title: Welcome to PY101
masteryOutcomes: Understand the course main topics and grading

lessons.title: Writing your first program
masteryOutcomes: Introduce the Maestro Code Editor
Write and execute a simple Python script using the print() function

lessons.title: Unlocking print() power-ups
masteryOutcomes: Print multiple values using commas
Understand that printing is always in a new line
Print multiple text and numeric values using the + and * operators.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Hello message board
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice writing and running simple Python scripts that use print() to display different kinds of messages on separate lines. Output: A script that prints a short multi-line ‚Äúmessage board‚Äù with greetings and simple text/number combinations.

lessons.title: Introduction to variables
masteryOutcomes: Explain that a variable is a named placeholder for a value in memory.
Write a valid variable name following Python conventions.
Assign a value (e.g., a number or a piece of text) to a variable using the = operator.
Use the print() function to display the value stored in a variable.

lessons.title: Working with text
masteryOutcomes: Define a "data type" as a category of data that determines what you can do with it.
Create a string variable by enclosing text in single (') or double (") quotes.
Combine two strings using the + operator (concatenation).
Predict the output when printing string variables.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Profile card
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use variables and strings to store basic profile information and print it out in a clear, formatted way using concatenation. Output: A script that prints a simple ‚Äúprofile card‚Äù (name, age, favorite hobby) built from string variables.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Story snippets
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Reinforce working with string variables and concatenation by assembling a short story from separate text pieces and predicting its printed output. Output: A script that prints a short, coherent story made by joining multiple string variables.

lessons.title: Working with numbers
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish between an integer (int, a whole number) and a float (float, a number with a decimal).
Create variables to store integer and float values.
Perform basic arithmetic operations (+, -, *, /) on numeric variables.
Explain why 5 is different from "5".

lessons.title: Modeling real-world calculations
masteryOutcomes: Translate a two-step word problem into an arithmetic expression and compute the result.
Do arithmetic directly inside print() to produce clear, useful outputs.
Compare two equivalent formulations and choose the clearer one.

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply integer and float variables with arithmetic operators to model a small purchase scenario and compute totals. Output: A script that calculates and prints the total cost of several snack items, including at least one float price.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Distance tracker
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Exercise goals and desired output: Translate a two-step word problem into numeric variables and arithmetic expressions, then print clear explanations of the results. Output: A script that calculates and prints total and average distance covered over several days using integers and floats.

lessons.title: Review: writing your first program
masteryOutcomes: Review and consolidate key concepts from writing and running first Python programs
Demonstrate basic proficiency with variables, data types, and print() through practice

lessons.title: Division modes: / vs // with quotient and remainder
masteryOutcomes: Compute and contrast true division (/) and floor division (//) on integers
explain the difference.
Use // and % together to derive quotient and remainder for practical cases (e.g., packing/scheduling).

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Concepts checkup
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Review and solidify understanding of variables, data types, and print() through written prediction, matching, and error-spotting exercises (no coding).

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Box packing planner
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use /, //, and % to compute and clearly display how many full boxes can be packed and how many items remain unpacked in a logistics scenario. Output: A script that prints the quotient and remainder for packing items into boxes, showing full boxes, leftover items, and any fractional comparison using true division.

lessons.title: Checking the facts
masteryOutcomes: Use type() to check a variable's data type
Use the str(), int(), and float() functions to convert values between data types.

lessons.title: Talking to your program: getting input from users
masteryOutcomes: Explain why programs interact with users and when input() is appropriate
collect input with clear prompts.
Convert numeric inputs to the correct type before computing and print a friendly summary.

Output: A script that asks the user about a habit, converts numeric answers, and prints a friendly typed summary of their daily habit stats.

Output: A script that asks the user about subjects and planned study time, converts inputs to numbers, and prints a simple study plan summary with totals.

lessons.title: Python errors: meet the traceback
masteryOutcomes: Understand why Python provides a traceback and how it helps identify what went wrong
Identify parts of a traceback and different types of tracebacks

lessons.title: Challenge: core foundations
masteryOutcomes: Student demonstrates understanding and can successfully complete the required skills for this challenge.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Traceback detective quiz

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Output: A completed quiz where the learner labels parts of tracebacks, identifies error types, and selects the most likely bug descriptions for each.

lessons.title: Functions i: why, define, and call
masteryOutcomes: Understand how functions reduce repetition and improve reuse.
Understand the structure of Python functions
Define a function with one or two parameters and call it with literals and variables

lessons.title: Functions ii: inside the function
masteryOutcomes: Understand the structure of a function, including its name, parameters, indentation, and return value.
Call functions with arguments correctly and trace how values are passed from the call site to parameters, verifying the flow using print statements.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Fitness calculator functions - Part 1

This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice defining simple functions with one or two parameters and calling them with both literals and variables to reduce repetition. Output: A script that defines and calls small fitness-related functions (e.g., calories_burned, minutes_to_hours) and prints the computed values.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Fitness calculator functions - Part 2

lessons.title: Functions iii: return vs print and early return
masteryOutcomes: Differentiate printing vs returning values
Use return to pass results and apply early returns.

lessons.title: Scope and local variables
masteryOutcomes: Understand that variables created inside a function exist only within that function‚Äôs scope (local).
Explain how local and global scopes differ and identify when each is used.
Demonstrate how data can be passed into functions through parameters instead of relying on global variables.

Output: A script where budget functions compute and return totals or remaining amounts, and the main code prints formatted budget summaries using those returned values.

lessons.title: Logical operators: and/or/not and short-circuiting
masteryOutcomes: Combine comparisons with and, or, not to form compound conditions.
Show short-circuit behavior by adding prints to the right-hand side expression.

lessons.title: Booleans and comparisons: equality vs identity
masteryOutcomes: Use True/False in expressions and store boolean results in variables.
Differentiate between '==' (value equality) and 'is' (identity equality).

lessons.title: String membership with 'in' in conditions
masteryOutcomes: Test substring membership with 'in' and negate with 'not in'.
Use membership checks inside if/elif branches to drive simple decisions.

lessons.title: Elif and refactoring nested decisions
masteryOutcomes: Refactor a nested if/else into an equivalent if/elif/else chain.
Order conditions to avoid overlaps and unreachable branches.

lessons.title: Decision tables to branching logic
masteryOutcomes: Translate a 3-5 row decision table into clear if/elif/else code.
Verify mutual exclusivity and completeness of the conditions.

lessons.title: For loops and range(): counting iterations
masteryOutcomes: Write for loops with range(stop), range(start, stop), range(start, stop, step)
Accumulate a total across iterations and print the result.
Generate even/odd sequences and countdowns with range.

lessons.title: Meet the while loop
masteryOutcomes: Understand what a while loop is and when it is more suitable than for.
Understand the risk of infinite loops and explain how to prevent them.
Write a while loop to repeat actions until a condition changes.

lessons.title: Loop control: break and continue
masteryOutcomes: Understand when to exit a loop early with break versus letting it complete naturally.
Insert break to exit early on a condition and continue to skip an iteration.

lessons.title: Review: decisions and loops
masteryOutcomes: Review and integrate concepts from conditionals and loops
Solve mixed exercises that require choosing appropriate decision and loop structures

lessons.title: String skills upgrade i: indexing and slicing
masteryOutcomes: Access individual characters in a string using 0-based indexing.
Use slice notation [start:stop] and [start:stop:step] to extract substrings.
Use negative indices to access characters from the end of a string.

lessons.title: String skills upgrade ii: common methods

Split text and rejoin with delimiters
Handle whitespace and empty fields

lessons.title: Lists i: creating lists
masteryOutcomes: Create lists with literals and from range()
print length with len().
Explain that lists are mutable and show a visible effect of mutation.
Understand when a list is a better choice than separate variables.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply common string methods (strip, lower, replace, find, split/join) to normalize and clean user-generated text comments. Output: A script that takes a messy comment, removes extra spaces, normalizes case, censors a list of banned words, and prints a cleaned version plus basic info about found keywords.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Shopping list organizer
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice creating and mutating lists while deciding when a list is better than separate variables, using list literals, range(), len(), and visible mutations. Output: A script that builds a shopping list from user input, shows its length, updates items in place, and prints the final organized list.

lessons.title: Lists ii: indexing and slicing
masteryOutcomes: Access list elements by index and understand how indexing works.
Modify list elements and create sublists using slicing.
Handle out-of-range errors (IndexError) in list access.

lessons.title: Lists iii: mastering list iteration
masteryOutcomes: Use a for loop with range() and len() to iterate over indices and access list elements by their position.
Use a for loop to iterate directly over the values in a list and perform actions on each element.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Quiz score tracker

This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use list indexing and slicing to access, modify, and safely handle quiz scores while avoiding IndexError. Output: A script that stores quiz scores in a list, updates specific scores by index, prints sublists for different quiz ranges, and safely attempts to read indices with basic error handling.

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice iterating over lists using both index-based loops and direct value loops to compute summaries and generate feedback. Output: A script that processes a list of daily step counts, calculates totals and averages, labels each day as ‚Äúgoal met‚Äù or ‚Äúgoal missed,‚Äù and prints a short weekly summary.

lessons.title: Lists iv: common methods
masteryOutcomes: Modify a list in place with append, insert, remove, pop, and extend.

lessons.title: Ordering lists: sorted() vs .sort()
masteryOutcomes: Sort a list in place with .sort() and create a sorted copy with sorted().
Use sorted() parameters ('key' and 'reverse') to customize ordering and explain stability.

Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.

Exercise goals and desired output: Use core list methods (append, insert, remove, pop, extend) to build and modify a task list for a simple productivity tool. lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Movie ranking sorter
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
